channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Trump marks Earth Day with tree planting at the White House with Melania
item.description: President Donald Trump marked Earth Day at the White House on Wednesday by planting a tree with Melania Trump on the South Lawn.

item.title: Coronavirus: Death toll jumps 172 in lockdown-free Sweden
item.description: The 172 new fatalities in Sweden take the country's death toll from 1,765 to 1,937, far higher than in Denmark (384), Norway (169) or Finland (149).

item.title: Terrifying moment 'gunman' sparks chaos in Chatham by shooting at people from balcony
item.description: Armed officers and a helicopter from Kent Police raced to Chatham Dockside this morning where a man was seen shooting from his balcony as people shopped in the streets below.

item.title: Ed Sheeran's neighbours win battle to extend their back garden
item.description: Ed Sheeran's neighbour who lives in East Suffolk has been given permission to make his back garden bigger with a paddock area, which runs along the side of the pop star's estate.

item.title: Coronavirus is killing patients with silent hypoxia, or low oxygen
item.description: Emergency room doctors say coronavirus patients are coming into the hospital with pneumonia and low oxygen levels, but they aren't struggling to breathe, meaning they are in critical condition already.

item.title: People share their DIY disasters as they attempt home improvements during lockdown
item.description: For people all over the world, lockdown has proved the perfect time to get started on some long-awaited home improvement projects - but for some, they didn't go to plan.

item.title: Welsh politician forgets to mute himself when he swears about Labour colleague in video chat
item.description: Health minister Vaughan Gething has apologised to Cardiff Central AM Jenny Rathbone after a conference call blunder in which he was heard muttering 'what the f*** is the matter with her?'

item.title: Welsh politician forgets to mute himself when he swears about Labour colleague in video chat
item.description: Health minister Vaughan Gething has apologised to Cardiff Central AM Jenny Rathbone after a conference call blunder in which he was heard muttering 'what the f*** is the matter with her?'

item.title: More than 40,000 cards pour in for Captain Tom's 100th birthday as team prepare Spitfire for flypast
item.description: Captain Tom Moore, who crowdfunded over £28million by walking 100 laps of his garden in Bedfordshire, has been flooded with more than 40,000 letters ahead of his centenary on April 30.

item.title: Chris Woakes says England players have wondered if they suffered with coronavirus
item.description: Almost the whole squad were stricken by two sickness bugs, the first a type of flu and the second a stomach problem, that weakened England in their heavy first Test defeat over Christmas.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Car theft rises 60% during lockdown
item.description: Car theft has rocketed by up to 60 per cent in parts of the UK as experts warn British motorists their vehicles are at greater risk during the lockdown (pictured, MailOnline map showing rise of car thefts).

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Duncan Bannatyne blasts Richard Branson
item.description: The Dragon's Den star said the billionaire Virgin Group boss should instead go to a bank for help and also hit out at his offer to mortgage Necker Island, his home in the Caribbean.

item.title: Boy, four, is eaten alive by stray PIGS after wandering out of his house to play in India
item.description: Four-year-old V. Harshavardhan was killed and eaten by a herd of wild pigs near his home in Hyderbad, India. He was playing in an isolated area near his home when the animals dragged him off.

item.title: Coronavirus Australia: Just FOUR people test positive in a day
item.description: The country's handling of the COVID-19 crisis has made it one of the safest places in the world, as the infection rate continues to drop - known as flattening the curve.

item.title: Dominic Raab delivers a rebuke to lockdown looseners
item.description: First Secretary Dominic Raab said it was not the time to 'take our eye off the ball' as he rejected claims the government is preparing to ease the draconian curbs in mid-May.

item.title: British £58m EuroMillions jackpot winner is revealed as 'hard-working joiner' and father-of-one
item.description: Ryan Hoyle, a 38-year-old joiner from Rochdale, Greater Manchester, has been revealed as the EuroMillions winner of £58million, seeing him rank ninth on the National Lottery millionaires' list.

item.title: Coronavirus: LA data suggests REAL death rate is 0.18%
item.description: Britain has one of the worst COVID-19 testing records, meaning a frightening 13% of diagnosed patients die. But antibody studies suggest the true death rate is closer to 0.18%.

item.title: David Beckham offers fans the chance to play football with him in support of COVID-19 relief
item.description: David Beckham has offered his fans the chance to go up against him and his football team at their home ground in support of COVID-19 relief.

item.title: Pocket-sized device could detect COVID-19 in less than two hours
item.description: A DNA testing kit that uses the heat of a smartphone could diagnose COVID-19 in under two hours. It identifies changes in DNA that signal disease in real time from samples of blood, urine or saliva.

item.title: The Earth's tectonic activity started more than 3.2 billion years ago, study finds
item.description: A team of geologists led by experts at Harvard University looked for clues of tectonic plate activity in ancient rocks more than 3 billions years old.

item.title: Italy's daily coronavirus death toll falls to 437, but new cases climb
item.description: As new cases and fatalities increased, Italy saw a drop in the number of people currently infected with the disease for the third day in a row. Deaths climbed by 437 down from 534 yesterday.

item.title: WHO warns coronavirus 'will be with us for a long time' and most of world's population is at risk
item.description: The World Health Organization (WHO) director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus (pictured) warned we have a long way to go and 'this virus will be with us for a long time'.

item.title: NHS staff criticised for dancing
item.description: Groups of nurses from wards in the likes of London, Buckinghamshire, Leeds and Wolverhampton have created the videos using the TikTok app.

item.title: Unexplained extra deaths show coronavirus death toll is FAR higher than official figures
item.description: Excess mortality figures - the number of deaths that occur above seasonal averages - from 13 countries and regions have revealed some 31,000 deaths not being counted in official totals.

item.title: Twitter's Jack Dorsey gives nearly $400m less to charity than the $1 billion he claimed
item.description: Dorsey tweeted that he would donate a billion dollars in the form of shares in Square to help coronavirus efforts but Securities Exchange Filings show he has donated less than that.

item.title: GP, two paramedics and mental health worker are latest NHS workers to die from coronavirus
item.description: Charlie Goodwin, 61, who worked as an ambulance driver for First 4 Care, passed away at King's Mill Hospital, Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, on April 20 after contracting Covid-19.

item.title: Rail union claims Government has 'concrete plans' to ease rail shutdown in THREE WEEKS' time
item.description: The TSSA trade union claims its members have been told of 'concrete plans' to bring the number of daily trains up to what would be a regular weekend service by the middle of May.

item.title: One third think their household will need financial support from taxpayers in next three months
item.description: Research firm Kantar surveyed more than 1,100 Brits after the coronavirus outbreak, in which nearly half felt their job was less safe than a year ago, but six in 10 feel the crisis is being handled well.

item.title: Coronavirus killed more Americans in one month than both flu and car accidents do in an entire YEAR
item.description: The coronavirus presents far more fatal risk than seasonal flu or car crashes and has fast become 'one of the leading causes of death in the United States', says a fellow at the National Review Institute.

item.title: Experts reveal how to stop quarantine from ruining your skin
item.description: A number of A-list skincare pros have revealed that clients are struggling with a host of skincare woes while in quarantine, particularly bad breakouts.

item.title: Donald Trump orders Navy to 'shoot down and destroy' Iranian gunboats if they harass American ships
item.description: The order, given by tweet, came hours after Iran's Revolutionary Guards Corps said it had launched the country's first military satellite into orbit. U.S. Navy patrols reported harassment last week.

item.title: Liverpool pay heartfelt tribute to the NHS and frontline workers during coronavirus pandemic
item.description: The Premier League club shared a touching message of appreciation as it was announced the UK suffered 759 more coronavirus deaths, taking the total past 18,000.

item.title: Queen 'desperately prayed for a baby brother' when being told she would be monarch
item.description: In 1936, Her Majesty, now 94, discovered she would be next inline to the throne, and started hoping for a baby brother, claims hisotrian Robert Lacey in tonight's Our Queen At War on ITV.

item.title: Jurgen Klopp's wife Ulla hands out £1,000 of food vouchers to Waitrose staff
item.description: Ulla Sandrock, who is married to the Liverpool F.C manager, visited a Waitrose store in Formby, Merseyside last week and handed out £50 vouchers to staff on the shop floor.

item.title: Spain sends back second batch of faulty coronavirus tests made in China
item.description: Spain's Health Ministry confirmed on Wednesday that they are now seeking a refund from Bioeasy for the entire order of 640,000 testing kits.

item.title: Jersey agrees to buy 500,000 coronavirus antibody tests - enough to test its population FIVE TIMES
item.description: The first 10,000 tests are being rigorously analysed by the government to make sure they are reliable enough. If they are, an 'Island-wide testing programme' will begin.

item.title: Spain's annual tomato battle scrapped due to coronavirus following cancellation of Pamplona bull run
item.description: The Spanish fiesta La Tomatina, in which 20,000 revellers pelt each other with tomatoes in the town of Bunol, Valencia, has been cancelled because of coronavirus, Mayor Junica Carrascosa has confirmed.

item.title: Chief Medical Officer admits there have been local shortages of PPE
item.description: Professor Chris Whitty said that supplies have been 'tight at different times for different items' and sometimes it has been 'very, very close to the line'.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 18,100 with 759 new fatalities
item.description: NHS England today said 665 more people have died in its hospitals after testing positive for COVID-19, the youngest of whom was 26. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland also announced more victims.

item.title: Prince Charles releases hard-hitting message for Earth Day
item.description: The Prince of Wales has released a hard-hitting message to mark Earth Day amid the coronavirus pandemic, stating: 'Air, water, soil and landscapes are vital to human health and wellbeing..

item.title: Stargazers get incredible sight of Lyrid meteor shower
item.description: The Lyrids takes its name from the constellation of Lyra the Harp, where the shooting stars appear to originate from. The celestial display peaked last night and was visible until early this morning.

item.title: 12 shipwrecks uncovered in the east Med dating from 300 BC
item.description: A British-led expedition has uncovered 12 shipwrecks in the eastern Mediterranean sea, including one colossal 17th century ship containing porcelain, jugs and illicit tobacco pipes.

item.title: Health Secretary Matt Hancock admits he 'can't promise' all Britons will be given free face masks
item.description: In the House of Commons, Mr Hancock warned it was vital to ensure the limited supplies of PPE are prioritised for frontline NHS and care home workers on the frontline of the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: Pope warns mankind has 'ruined the work of God and sinned against the Earth' on World Earth Day
item.description: During his address on the 50th anniversary of the first World Earth Day (pictured) Pope Francis spoke about how he sees natural tragedies are 'the Earth's response to our maltreatment.'

item.title: Winter wave of coronavirus could be even more devastating than the current crisis, experts say
item.description: Dr Joe Grove, a virologist at University College London, said with no vaccine and a lack of immunity, there was nothing stopping a second wave from overwhelming the NHS.

item.title: It's cyber Crufts! Kennel Club launches online dog show for pedigrees and crossbreeds
item.description: The Kennel Club, the organisation behind the prestigious event, has launched an online dog show for pet owners across the UK who are stuck indoors during lockdown.

item.title: Zoom update lets users report meeting participants and lock video calls to prevent 'Zoombombing'
item.description: Among the new features is the ability to lock meetings and prevent other users from joining, the ability to remove participants in the meeting and greater control over screen sharing.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: A third of homeworkers aren't setting alarms
item.description: A study for 23andMe found that the average wake-up time for people working from home had shifted by 48 minutes to 7.06am from 6.18am before the pandemic.

item.title: Police say it is a 'disgrace' that thug has avoided jail after coughing in officer's face
item.description: Inspector Matt Webb (pictured) described the sentence as 'staggering' as Trevor Dangerfield, 39, avoided jail after coughing in an officer's face at a property in St Leonards, East Sussex last Friday.

item.title: Fashion chain Animal is to close its 21 UK stores putting 500 jobs at risk
item.description: Fashion retailer Animal will close down permanently in January after its owners H Young Holdings Ltd confirmed the Poole-based business was losing money.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, 70, ignores safety advice to attend Commons on first day of 'virtual' session
item.description: The Islington North MP took his seat on the deserted backbenches despite official guidance that those aged 70 and over should limit their movement outside their homes.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Keir Starmer attacks Dominic Raab over PPE
item.description: Standing in for Boris Johnson in the Commons, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab defended the painful progress towards the target of 100,000 tests a day by the end of the month.

item.title: Kim Jong Un's death could force US and South Korea to take military action
item.description: A power vacuum left by the dictator could explode into an ugly civil war in the North Korea, which would spark 'humanitarian suffering' and a wave of refugees fleeing the violence.

item.title: Hawaiian volcano eruption in 2018 was triggered by sustained rainfall
item.description: Excessive and sustained rainfall triggered 2018 Kīlauea volcano eruption by softening the volcanic rock, which breaks more easily under pressure from magma, according to a new study.

item.title: Tesco shop workers will start getting tested for coronavirus within days
item.description: In a letter to customers, chief executive Dave Lewis said Tesco will begin to trial testing for its workers in one region of the UK. Voluntary testing will be available for around 200 staff.

item.title: Couple transform guest bedroom door into bookcase
item.description: Carrie and Kyle Dorr, from Saint Michael, Minnesota, transformed the door to their guest bedroom by removing it from its hinges and attaching shelves to create the appearance of a bookcase.

item.title: Man, 44, will be kept in a secure hospital for life after strangling mother-of-four to death
item.description: Mother-of-four Pamela Ann Mellor, 55, was strangled during a sustained and brutal assault by boyfriend Matthew Bolland, 44, at a flat in Handforth, Cheshire, last August.

item.title: MPs juggle politics with babysitting as they take part in historic first virtual Commons from home
item.description: Politicians taking part in Prime Minister's Questions from the safety and comfort of their own homes were upstaged by their grandchildren and their interior design sense - or lack of it.

item.title: Four of the government's hastily-built NHS Nightingales lie near-empty
item.description: The first of the seven sites in England to open at the ExCel in London has so far treated just 41 patients despite having a capacity of 500 - the same as sites in Harrogate, Manchester and Birmingham.

item.title: Skier's terrifying brush with death in France when he is engulfed by a fast-moving avalanche
item.description: The shocking footage shows a snow slide in France heading for a male who has no idea it is coming while he is skiing off-piste. It hits him and miraculously he survives thanks to his airbag.

item.title: Average European carries more than 500 genetic fragments from Neanderthals and other archaic humans
item.description: The ancestors of Europeans are known to have mated with Neanderthals and other archaic humans more than 50,000 years ago - trading genetic material.

item.title: Emirates A380 Airbus was 25 seconds away from smashing into a Moscow suburb
item.description: An Emirates A380 airbus, the largest airliner in the world, was just 25 seconds away from crashing into a Moscow suburb as the crew mistakenly believed the plane was too high for landing.

item.title: France and Holland are latest nations to re-open schools
item.description: French primary school children are due to return to their classrooms on May 11 with a maximum of around 15 children per class.

item.title: Merseyside nursery teacher upstaged by horses as she records lockdown story time video for her kids
item.description: Eloise Roberts, from Moreton, Merseyside, was shocked when her horses interrupted her story time video with an x-rated display. The 32-year-old burst out laughing at the amorous horses.

item.title: Thug jailed for beating up man is in prison after smashing lantern over his nurse girlfriend's head
item.description: Thug David Newlands (pictured) has been jailed for 20 months after attacking his former lover Jennifer Watson at her home in Glasgow when he suspected her of cheating on him.

item.title: ICU doctor who lost colleagues to Covid-19 reveals he wrote love letter to wife with final wishes
item.description: Dr Matt Morgan, 40, of Cardiff, told The Times the blue sofas are being used more than ever, and he and his colleagues are taking on the role of loved-ones for patients in their final moments.

item.title: Royal Navy's newest £3.1 billion aircraft carrier's noisy engines are keeping neighbours up at night
item.description: The aircraft carrier has caused 'incessant noise pollution' with its diesel engines. Homeowners and a councillor in Gosport, Hants, have complained of the racket during the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Take a virtual tour of newly excavated sections of Pompeii thanks to never-before-seen drone footage
item.description: The footage sweeps around the excavation of Regio V, a 54-acre archaeological site where, over the past two years, experts have discovered a trove of extraordinary finds.

item.title: Once-ridiculed motors now claimed to be worth a pretty penny
item.description: The 'crap classics' list is made up of models that have seen a surge in demand - and value - as nostalgic previous owners look to regain some part of their youth with cars they drove years ago.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Brighton beach barbecue couple fined £60
item.description: Police tried to move the couple on who were having a barbecue on Brighton beach. Sussex Force has issued fixed penalty notices to them to pay a £60 fine.

item.title: Desperate appeal after heartless thieves steal flags and pictures from WWII memorial
item.description: Thieves snatched tributes to 10 US airmen from Endcliffe Park in Sheffield, where in 1944 the heroic servicemen crashed as he desperately swerved to avoid a group of children.

item.title: Government launches bizarre series of corny coronavirus adverts to get them shared online
item.description: The adverts, which include deliberate errors, are designed to be mocked online so that people share them and spread the 'stay at home' message.

item.title: Apocalyptic scenes in Chernobyl as drone footage reveals devastation
item.description: Firefighters fought back the flames for almost two weeks, hyper-aware that the inferno was creeping towards the site of the exploded nuclear plant in Chernobyl, Ukraine.

item.title: Four women and two men are arrested for money laundering and slavery after police raid brothels
item.description: Six people have been arrested following raids by the Metropolitan Police of brothels in Westminster and £1m of luxury goods have been seized from those accused of profiting from proceeds of crime.

item.title: Colon cancer survivor recreated famous celebrity photographs showcasing her stoma bag
item.description: Sarah Mills, 36, from Tenterden, Kent, survived stage 3 colon cancer and now lives with a stoma bag. She recreated famous celebrity portrait to show that the pouch was nothing to be ashamed of.

item.title: Woman reveals we've all been sealing cereal boxes wrong
item.description: British TikTok user Katy Bee left followers amazed when she revealed that you've probably been closing cereal boxes all wrong, and shared her trick for doing it the right way.

item.title: Judge brands thug 'disgusting social menace' as he jails him for urinating on war memorial
item.description: Mark Smith, 58, was spotted on CCTV by council staff urinating on the cenotaph war memorial in St Peter's Square, Manchester, and he has since been jailed for more than two years.

item.title: Sales of barbecue food soar as Britain prepares to bask in 75F mini heatwave
item.description: Temperatures will hit 71F (22C) today for many parts of the country - but London is forecast to see even more warm weather and sunshine on Thursday as the heatwave continues.

item.title: Mystery surrounds arrival of five massive cargo ships and an oil tanker off Welsh coast
item.description: Six massive vessels are anchored in the Bristol Channel as they wait to dock at Port Talbot after the first of them arrived at the weekend.

item.title: Couple 'unaware' of Covid-19 pandemic as they were sailing across the ocean
item.description: Briton Ryan Osborne, right, and Elena Manighetti from Italy, left, were unaware of the Covid-19 pandemic as they had been sailing across the Atlantic ocean without access to the internet.

item.title: Teen robber chases a dog walker and his dog with machete
item.description: Alfie Bould used a machete to rob a 28-year-old man walking his parents' dog in Sandbach, Staffordshire. Bould chased after him violently swinging the machete at the victim and the dog.

item.title: PIERS MORGAN: I understand why Americans are protesting the lockdown - but they're wrong
item.description: The US, which despite all President Trump's claims to the contrary, was shamefully slow to respond to the threat, has had more coronavirus deaths than anywhere else in the world.

item.title: Disabled woman opts NOT to have a ramp in renovation on Your Home Made Perfect
item.description: Wheelchair user Paula, who has MS, and Jeremy, who own a Victorian four-bedroom house in Halifax, appeared on the BBC2 show last night, to modify their inaccessibe conservatory,

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Calls for inquiry over Cheltenham Festival
item.description: Gloucestershire Hospitals NHS Trust has recorded 125 deaths from the disease so far, more than double those in nearby Swindon with 67, Bristol on 58 and Bath on 46.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Over-50s should stay at home to protect NHS
item.description: Official data - collated by the Intensive Care National Audit and Research Centre from NHS critical care units - shows 54 per cent of COVID-19 patients are between 50 and 69.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Woman, 22, dies before dad can say goodbye
item.description: The heartbroken dad of a 'loving daughter who never stopped laughing' has paid tribute to her after she tragically passed away aged just 22 after contracting coronavirus.

item.title: JK Rowling shares a glimpse into her impressive library as she reorganises her book collection
item.description: J.K Rowling took to Twitter yesterday afternoon to reveal how she's passing the time by rearranging her books. She shared a short video of her home library, which features teal, wooden panelled walls.

item.title: Conor McGregor loses three-year legal battle with clothing firm founded by businessman 100 years ago
item.description: The former UFC champion, 31, cannot use his own name for his sportswear brand. McGregor New York, founded in 1921 by Scotsman David Doniger, won the legal battle.

item.title: Hospital staff pay tribute to 'devoted' father-of-four surgeon, 58, after he died from coronavirus
item.description: Touching footage filmed from Sadeq Elhowsh's hearse shows hospital staff in Merseyside lining the street before bursting into a round of applause for the surgeon after he died from coronavirus.

item.title: Alleged fraudster 'conned elderly residents out of cash by claiming he was collecting for charity'
item.description: Philip Cutler is accused of going into St Catherine's Court nursing home (pictured) on Wheatstone Rd, Gloucester, on April 6 asking residents to donate money to charity.

item.title: Greta Thunberg says coronavirus and climate change must be tackled together
item.description: The 17-year-old marked Earth Day with a live-streamed appeal from Sweden to 'tackle two crises at once', saying the pandemic showed the importance of listening to scientists.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Care Minister slammed for PPE failure
item.description: Care Minister Helen Whately this morning said the UK government is currently changing the way it collects data in relation to deaths caused by the coronavirus.

item.title: Banksy's world famous Girl with a Pierced Eardrum is given a coronavirus twist
item.description: The Bristol artwork, which appeared overnight in October 2014 was fitted with a surgical style face mask during the ongoing coronavirus lockdown. The mural is based on the Vermeer painting.

item.title: Groom downs shots and licks a dog bowl dressed as Luigi as friends throw virtual stag party on Zoom
item.description: Dan Marshall, from Worcester, dressed up as Luigi, from popular video game Super Mario Bros, before enjoying a boozy party via Zoom with his friends, on what should have been his stag night.

item.title: Military 'appalled' at coronavirus PPE fiasco in NHS
item.description: NHS bosses are under pressure today after military staff attacked the health service for the way it has been distributing vital PPE equipment during the coronavirus crisis.

item.title: House prices started to slow before lockdown, says ONS / Land Registry
item.description: House price inflation slowed from 1.5 per cent in January to 1.1 per cent in February, the Office for National Statistics and Land Registry index reported

item.title: Violent thief threatened MP 'I'm going to murder you' then punched him in the face
item.description: Robert Largan, 32, was punched in the face in Broadbottom, Hyde, when he tried to pursue Leslie Thorley, who had grabbed his £800 iPhone X during 'a tussle' on a train journey from Glossop.

item.title: Stunning 14th Century coach house in Devon village goes on the market for £975,000
item.description: The Grade I listed house, which boasts five bedrooms, is in the heart of Lustleigh, a Dartmoor village in Devon, and is on the market, along with a two-bedroom cottage, for £975,000.

item.title: Amazing drone footage shows feeding blue whales swimming to the surface
item.description: Experts from Oregon State University found that feeding on the ocean's surface plays an important role in the hunt for food among New Zealand blue whales.

item.title: Butterfly charity urges British public to report garden sightings during the coronavirus lockdown
item.description: Butterfly Conservation has been taking comprehensive surveys of Britain's butterfly and moth populations for the last 50 years.

item.title: Motorist captures images of 'muscular big cat' thought to be a puma roaming the British countryside
item.description: The photos match other sightings of big cats in Bowness-on-Windermere, totalling more than 40 since 2003. The woman said the puma was eating a pigeon when she spotted it and took three pictures.

item.title: Pictured: Moment Paul Gascoigne broke social distancing rules inside Morrisons supermarket
item.description: The famous ex-footballer was seen greeting fans and getting very close to strangers for photographs at Morrisons in Bridlington, Yorkshire, on April 9, as he reportedly went shopping for a BBQ.

item.title: Childhood sweethearts who began dating aged 13 rekindle their romance and plan to marry
item.description: Beth Fenwick and Steven Lyons, both 24, from Somerset, first dated when they were aged just 13, with Beth keeping a diary of their romance. After drifting apart, they met again and fell in love.

item.title: New snake species named after Harry Potter character Salazar Slytherin
item.description: The green venomous snake has been named Trimeresurus salazar after the Hogwarts house founder, but will be commonly known as Salazar's pit viper.

item.title: Vets baffled after Frankie the Jack Russell-cross was born with hair growing through his EYEBALLS
item.description: Tracey Smith, 43, from Tunbridge Wells, Kent spotted the unique pooch, while delivering car parts to a local working farm, and noticed he had small tufts of hair sprouting through both of his eyes.

item.title: Japan cuts down 100,000 tulips to discourage people from gathering
item.description: Just a few weeks ago, thousands of the bright flowers blanketed fields in the city of Sakura, east of Tokyo, drawing locals eager to glimpse them in full bloom.

item.title: Heartbroken family of missing estate agent Chelsie Dack fear she may have killed herself
item.description: Norfolk Police said CCTV footage showed Chelsie Dack walking towards the pier, where her mobile phone was found by a member of the public later that morning.

item.title: Home cooks share their attempts to make PizzaExpress staples in their kitchen
item.description: Pizza Express fans across the UK have taken to social media to show off their creations, after following the chain's recipe for Margherita Pizza and Dough Balls - and the results are impressive.

item.title: Mysterious hacker returns £20m crypto-currencies after stealing it from dForce
item.description: A sum of £20million worth of assets was illegally drained from the crypto trading site on Sunday, according to the founder of dForce. But the hacker reportedly returned all the funds today.

item.title: easyJet lets customers book holidays for Easter 2021 after bringing sale date forward five months
item.description: The budget airline, which earlier this month secured a £600 million loan from the Treasury and the Bank of England's coronavirus fund, has started the sale earlier in a desperate bid to attract sales.

item.title: Woman, 57, claims she looks ten years younger thanks to collagen stimulating filler and threads
item.description: Paula Nugent, 57, from Cheltenham, who says she was left prematurely aged by sun damage, has claimed she now looks 10 years younger after having collagen stimulating filler and threads.

item.title: Grieving mum slams thug who hacked her son, 17, to death
item.description: Kyle Yule, 17, was fatally stabbed in October 2017 near his home in Gillingham, Kent when five thugs hunted him to his friend's front door before savagely attacking him with knives and machetes.

item.title: Tony Blair warns decisions on coronavirus lockdown must be taken NOW
item.description: Tony Blair said Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab and senior ministers must make crucial choices on releasing schools, regions and sectors to avoid huge damage to the economy.

item.title: Coronavirus tests given to NHS staff to let them return to work 'are FLAWED'
item.description: A leaked Public Health England document revealed testing centres had been told to stop using the kits because of 'quality assurance difficulties'.

item.title: The number of women accusing Peter Nygard of sexual assault has increased FIVE-FOLD
item.description: The original lawsuit of 10 accusers was filed against the 78-year-old Canadian in February, when FBI raided his Manhattan office.

item.title: Jellyfish is spotted swimming through Venice's unusually clean canals
item.description: Zoologist Andrea Mangoni filmed the creature swimming in 'exceptionally calm' waters near Venice's Bareteri Bridge last week.

item.title: Classic Ferrari 250 GTE used by the Polizia in Rome in the 1960s is up for sale
item.description: The Ferrari 250 spend six years in service chasing criminals through the streets of Rome, making it the most stylish paddy wagon to have patrolled roads.

item.title: Can you find the halloumi in this quarantine-themed garden BBQ brainteaser?
item.description: The puzzle, released by British retirement homes Audley Villages, will help transport some players to brighter BBQ days in the sunshine. But can you find the single slice of halloumi?

item.title: Baby elephant leaves perfect impression of his head and trunk in the sand at Chester Zoo
item.description: One-year-old Anjan left this near-perfect imprint of his head and trunk after nodding off in the sand in his enclosure at Chester Zoo. The Asian elephant was named after a conservationist in India.

item.title: Prince Charles reveals he watches viral videos during coronavirus lockdown a
item.description: Prince Charles has praised the 'crucial role' of home-grown producers in keeping the country fed and revealed he entertained himself during his time in lockdown by watching funny videos.

item.title: Battle of Britain hero thought to have been inspiration for Tom Hardy's character in Dunkirk
item.description: A Battle of Britain hero thought to have been the real life inspiration for Tom Hardy's character in the film Dunkirk has been revealed after his bravery medals emerged for sale.

item.title: Donald Trump says immigration is 'paused' for 60 days
item.description: President Donald Trump said on Tuesday his immigration ban would be a 60-day pause on green cards, which is already in place because of the coronavirus.

item.title: Greta Thunberg launches video of family walking around burning house
item.description: The shocking clip shows a family walking around a burning house at an undisclosed location. It ends with: 'Our house is on fire. React.'

item.title: British 'jihadi rapper' was 'snuck into Spain by boat after posing as an undocumented migrant'
item.description: Spanish state broadcaster TVE said the jihadi reached the city of Almeria in a patera, the wooden boats Africans traditionally use to reach Europe from as far afield as Senegal.

item.title: Canada killer 'obsessed with mounties' had an alcohol problem
item.description: Gabriel Wortman, the 51-year-old gunman who was shot dead after a 12-hour killing and arson spree across Nova Scotia, was also said to have an obsession with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

item.title: Savvy mother transforms dull patch of grass into a pink paradise garden… for just £725
item.description: Chrissie Bray, 45, spent two years creating her dream garden in Birmingham. She came up with the idea of a pink paradise outside after being rediagnosed with breast cancer in 2018

item.title: Lady Pamela Hicks shares her memories of Prince Philip's mother Princess Alice
item.description: Lady Pamela Hicks, 90, daughter of Philip's maternal uncle Lord Mountbatten, told how the Queen, 94, has a talent for 'getting the best' out of people in conversation with daughter India Hicks.

item.title: Police hunt Prince Harry lookalike after serious assault in Glasgow left man, 23, in hospital
item.description: Officers in Scotland today released CCTV images of two men they would like to speak to following the assault in Glasgow at around 12.20am on Sunday, February 23.

item.title: Coronavirus: Virgin Australia goes into administration
item.description: Flight attendants have asked for help to save jobs at Virgin Australia after it went into administration, with some saying goodbyes in emotional videos of their final flights.

item.title: Virgin Australia goes into voluntary administration putting 16,000 jobs at risk
item.description: The airline called in administrators Deloitte after a board meeting of its international shareholders voted against providing more financial support.

item.title: The story of Octopussy which broke the 50-knot barrier and became world's fastest superyacht
item.description: A new documentary has revealed how Heesen Yachts turned American businessman John Staluppi's dream of owning the world's fastest superyacht into a reality in 1988.

item.title: Mother's four-ingredient recipe for vanilla bites keeps her kids happy in lockdown
item.description: Adela Lovrencic discovered how to bake a tray of the miniature desserts with a sheet of ready-made puff pastry, milk, icing sugar and a packet of instant vanilla pudding for just $6.85.
item.media:credit: Share Kmart Air Fryer Recipes Australia Facebook
